title: 114_hr2144
content: The Act may be cited as the "Program Management Improvement and Accountability Act of 2015". It establishes a Deputy Director for Management. The Program Management Improvement and Accountability Act of 2015 establishes a Deputy Director for Management who is responsible for adopting governmentwide standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management, overseeing their implementation, chairing the Program Management Policy Council, issuing regulations, and engaging with the private sector. The Program Management Improvement and Accountability Act of 2015 mandates the Deputy Director for Management to issue standards, policies, and guidelines within 120 days of enactment, and regulations within 150 days. This includes conducting portfolio reviews, engaging with the private sector, and establishing a five-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Deputy Director for Management must issue regulations within 150 days of the enactment of the Program Management Improvement and Accountability Act of 2015 to implement section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 3. Program Management Improvement Officers and Policy Council. Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include the designation of Program Management Improvement Officers in agencies to implement program management policies and enhance the role of program managers. The amendment to Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code designates Program Management Improvement Officers in agencies to enhance program management policies. This includes enhanced training, mentoring, improved career paths, incentives for recruitment, and improved resources for program managers. The Program Management Improvement Officers in agencies aim to enhance program management policies by providing improved training, mentoring, career paths, recruitment incentives, and resources for program managers. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for improving agency practices. Key functions include collecting and disseminating best practices, providing common templates and tools for data analysis, and enhancing program management across the agency. The Program Management Policy Council is the principal interagency forum for improving agency practices related to program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses workforce development needs and policies for continuous improvement. The Program Management Policy Council advises on program management improvement, major challenges, and standards governmentwide. It is composed of five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council includes key members such as the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy, the Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, the Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management, the Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency, and other individuals as determined appropriate by the Chairperson. The Council is chaired by the Deputy Director for program management. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget is the Chairperson of the Council, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members. The Chairperson presides over meetings, sets the agenda, directs the work of the Council, and establishes subgroups as needed. The Council meets at least twice per fiscal year, with additional meetings called by the Chairperson or majority vote. Each agency with a Project provides support. The head of each agency with a Project Management Improvement Officer on the Council shall provide administrative support as requested by the Chairperson. A report must be submitted to Congress and the Office of Management and Budget within 180 days of the enactment of the Act, containing the strategy developed under section 1126(a)(2)(B) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. PROGRAM AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL STANDARDS. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 270 days of the Act's enactment. These regulations will identify key skills and competencies, establish a new job series, and create a career path for program and project managers within agencies.
